Afghan Hound.name: Afghan Hound
Afghan Hound.description: One of the oldest dog breeds, thought to be developed from Salukis. Its long coat protected it from the cold regions of Afghanistan. The breed is generally aloof and not obedient. It may need more than 2 hours of exercise.

African Hunting Dog.name: African Hunting Dog
African Hunting Dog.description: Its taxonomic name is Lycaon pictus which is different from the tradition dog: Canis familiaris. Lycaon lineage diverged from them about 2 million years ago. The breed forms very strong bonds with its pack and is rarely seen alone. Their natural enemies include hyenas and lions. They are an endangered species.

Airedale.name: Airedale
Airedale.description: Airedales were messengers in trenches during WW1 and are considered war heroes for their help. It has a strong sense of smell, making it a great tracking dog. They have also helped in the Red Cross.

American Staffordshire Terrier.name: American Staffordshire Terrier
American Staffordshire Terrier.description: Extremely similar to American Pit Bull Terriers and Staffordshire Bull Terrier. Ancestors are presumably the same as Staffordshire Bull Terrier from England. They are very loyal and protective.

Appenzeller.name: Appenzeller
Appenzeller.description: Historically used as a draft dog and general farm dog. They are now kept as companions and used in agility competitions.

Australian Shepherd.name: Australian Shepherd
Australian Shepherd.description: Historically used as a herding dog with its obedient nature and amazing ability to control livestock, it is now a popular companion dog. They are considered very playful.

Australian Terrier.name: Australian Terrier
Australian Terrier.description: The breed was developed in Australia with its ancestry from Great Britain. They are spirited, alert, and intelligent. Often affectionate to people and other dogs, but may not get along with other male dogs.

Bedlington Terrier.name: Bedlington Terrier
Bedlington Terrier.description: Historically bred to hunt, they are now often used in competitions to race and for companionship. They are very good swimmers and have great speed and endurance. Their appearance is similar to lambs and they shed very little with minimal odor.

Bernese Mountain Dog.name: Bernese Mountain Dog
Bernese Mountain Dog.description: Sennenhund-type are farm dogs originating from Swiss Alps. The Bernese has a large build and a calm temperament, often being friendly to even strangers. Unfortunately, they have one of the lowest average life expectancies.

Bichon Frise.name: Bichon Frise
Bichon Frise.description: Originally from the Canary Islands, they were bred as sailing and herding dogs. The French further bred them into a gentle lap-dog for companionship. Bichon Frise are intelligent, playful, and gentle.

Black Sable.name: Black Sable
Black Sable.description: They are the exact same breed as German Sheperd, but instead of the common tan and black fur, Black Sable has a rarer coat with darker colours and a sable pattern (many hues and colours in the coat).

Blenheim Spaniel.name: Blenheim Spaniel
Blenheim Spaniel.description: Also known as King Charles Spaniel, English Toy Spaniel, and Ruby Spaniel, they descended from larger hunting dogs. King Charles II of England loved this breed, hence its name, but there is no evidence the modern breed descended from his dogs. They have been used for hunting in the past as they kept their hunting instincts, but their small stature make them suited better as lapdogs. The modern breed suffers from cardiac and eye problems.

Border Collie.name: Border Collie
Border Collie.description: Border Collie is a working dog that was used to herd sheep. They are extremely energetic and workaholic. Having a job to perform that requires exercise and obedience will keep the breed very happy.

Border Terrier.name: Border Terrier
Border Terrier.description: Often easy to recognize due to their unique head shape and longer legs compared to other small terriers, the Border Terrier is good-tempered, affectionate, and obedient. They were bred as a country dog to help hunt foxes with their hunting instincts.

Boston Bull.name: Boston Bull
Boston Bull.description: Also known as the Boston Terrier or Boxwood, their lineage is of bull and terrier. They are an extremely gentle breed with a friendly personality and obedient nature, although they can be aggressive to protect their owners.

Bouvier des Flandres.name: Bouvier des Flandres
Bouvier des Flandres.description: Bouvier des Flandres were originally used as a general farm dog used to help herd sheep and pull carts. They had immense strength, good temperament, and can withstand weather conditions with its thick coat. The breed is now used as guard dogs and companions.

Brabancon Griffo.name: Brabancon Griffo
Brabancon Griffo.description: Other names include Griffon Bruxellois, Brussles Griffon, and Griffon Belge. Some have the recognizable beard, but can also have short hair, showing its underbite and short nose. Breeders often dock their tails and crop their ears which is illegal in most places. They are known to have a strong desire to snuggle with its owner

Brittany Spaniel.name: Brittany Spaniel
Brittany Spaniel.description: Brittany was bred primarily for bird hunting, solidly built without being large. They are athletic, easy to train, and intelligent. Their beautiful patterned coat (similar to a cow's coat) are coloured with vivid orange, reddish brown, and white.

Cane Carso.name: Cane Carso
Cane Carso.description: Cane Corso are an intimidating breed with their expression and large muscles bulging beneath their short coat. However, they are affectionate, loyal, and are easily trained. They can be very protective of their owners and properties.

Cardigan.name: Cardigan
Cardigan.description: Better known as Welsh Corgis, they are one of the oldest breeds of the British Isles originally used as farm guardians. Cardigans are extremely loyal, obedient, and hardworking. Despite their small stature and legs, they can be used as guard dogs and can be extremely athletic.

Chesapeake Bay Retriever.name: Chesapeake Bay Retriever
Chesapeake Bay Retriever.description: Chesapeake has a waterproof coat, allowing it to swim in icy waters for long periods of time without getting cold. Its curly hair is better at keeping its warmth compared to straight hair. They are protective and affectionate to their owners, but can be cold towards strangers.

Chihuahua.name: Chihuahua
Chihuahua.description: Chihuahuas are the smallest recognized breed. They can have long hair and unlike most long-haired breeds, they need minimal grooming. Due to excessive breeding, they have terrible eye and breathing problems and will feel terrible. Poorly trained Chihuahuas can be aggressive or excessively bark.

Chinese Crested Dog.name: Chinese Crested Dog
Chinese Crested Dog.description: There are hairless and haired variants (often called Powderpuff) which look very different. Hairlessness is a lethal dominant gene. That is to say, every surviving hairless variant has one hairless gene and every Powderpuff has two haired genes. The hairless variant has soft, human-like skin with fluffy hair on its head and paws like socks. Powderpuff has a long and silky, fluffy coat.

Dandie Dinmont.name: Dandie Dinmont
Dandie Dinmont.description: Recognized by their long body and topknot hair on their head, they were originally used for hunting badgers and otters. Dandie Dinmont are friendly but often challenge other animals including other dogs and small mammals. Compared to other terrier breeds, they are less demanding and more docile.

Doberman.name: Doberman
Doberman.description: With an intimidating stare and a muscular body highlighted by its short coat, Doberman was intended as a guard dog. Although their personalities can vary greatly, they are generally considered obedient, easy to train, loving, and devoted to their owners. Their aggression has been toned down by modern breeders to make them more appropriate for companionship role. They are ranked as one of the most intelligent breeds.

English Foxhound.name: English Foxhound
English Foxhound.description: The English Foxhound, cousin of the American Foxhound, have an amazing sense of smell and the stanima to run for long periods of time without breaks. These traits come from their original purpose of hunting and tracking foxes. Being a pack hound, the breed is social and gentle, getting well with other dogs and human companionship.

English Setter.name: English Setter
English Setter.description: Recognized by their freckled coat and long silky fringes under their body, the English Setter was bred for endurance and speed to hunt game. Their colour markings develop as they grow into adults and its colours can vary greatly. Like most gun dogs, they are good natured, intelligent, and obedient.

English Springer.name: English Springer
English Springer.description: The English Springer, like a typical Spaniel, are friendly, quick to learn, and obedient. They can make great hunting companions with their alertness and intelligence. However, they are prone to many hereditary health conditions which include blindless and hip dysplasia. They can become mischievous if not physically stimulated enough.

EntleBucher.name: EntleBucher
EntleBucher.description: The smallest of the four Switz Sennenhund dog breed with short, strong legs and a salient black, white, and tan coat. Entles are famous for their athleticism. As with most working dogs, they are social, good nature, and great companions given that they exercise a lot.

Eskimo Dog.name: Eskimo Dog
Eskimo Dog.description: The Greenland Dog, Canadian Husky, or the Canadian Eskimo Dog is a very rare purebred dog with only about 300 left. They are powerfully built, being preferred method of transportation by the Inuits as sled dogs. However, the rise of snowmobiles resulted in the breed's decline. The breed descended from the dogs of the Thule people 1000 years ago who used them for transportation in Siberia.

Fila Braziliero.name: Fila Braziliero
Fila Braziliero.description: Fila Braziliero or Brazilian Mastiff has some of the best hunting traits. They have amazing scenting abilities, aggressive yet protective temperament, and chooses to trap its prey rather than attacking it. Hence, they are often used as a guard dog, police dog, and cattle dog. Nonetheless, they can still be family dogs given enough training and exercise.

French Bulldog.name: French Bulldog
French Bulldog.description: Playful and adaptable, the French Bulldog are one of the most popular small dog breeds. Their large head with a short, wrinkled nose and a small, muscular body make them resemble a tiny bulldog. Yet, they are very friendly, quiet, and require little exercise which make them ideal for a small family dog.

German Shepherd.name: German Shepherd
German Shepherd.description: Intelligent, obedient, athletic, and easily trained, German Shepherds are one of the most popular breeds, especially for military roles and disability assistance. They are curious, protective, and eager to have a purpose, though they can be aggressive if not trained and stimulated properly. There are many variants of the breed, all with different coat colours and patterns.

German Short Haired Pointer.name: German Short Haired Pointer
German Short Haired Pointer.description: A versatile hunting breed for game on both land and water, they are very energetic and well socialized. Like all pointing breeds, they instinctively point their nose towards game, typically acquired at 2 months of age. Their long muzzle and legs allow them to retrieve lare game. They also have a dense undercoat, making them water resistant and allowing them to swim in cold water for longer periods of time.

Gordon Setter.name: Gordon Setter
Gordon Setter.description: Gordon Setter has a brilliant black coat with long fur covering their ears and belly. Their thick fur helps them withstand the tough weather in the British Isles. They are alert, intelligent, and affectionate towards their owner where they thrive with attention and care. They are one of the slowest breeds to mature.

Great Dane.name: Great Dane
Great Dane.description: The Great Dane towers over most other breeds with a height of nearly 1 meter. They are guardians, alert and protective of their owners and territory. Their coat comes in many colours and patterns including fawn, spotted, and steel blue.

Great Pyrenees.name: Great Pyrenees
Great Pyrenees.description: More commonly known as Patou, the Great Pyrenees were guardians that protected livestock from wolves and bears. Extremely protective and alert, they often wore a spiked collar to protect its neck when fighting wolves. Their thick double coat around its neck, legs, and belly provides itself protection from the cold weather near the Pyrenees Mountains.

Greater Swiss Mountain Dog.name: Greater Swiss Mountain Dog
Greater Swiss Mountain Dog.description: Like the other Sennenhund breeds, they are strong, obedient workers and bred for all-purpose farm duties with a unique tricolor coat. They are a very happy and enthusiastic breed that desires attention and socialization.

Ibizan Hound.name: Ibizan Hound
Ibizan Hound.description: Bred as a rabbit courser on Spain's islands, they are phenomenal sprinters and leapers. Their elegant, slim body with upright ears are often described as deer-like. Ibizans are intelligent and independent. They can be trained, but often instinctively climb ontop of objects and hunt small animals, so they are generally not trusted without a leash. Their coat is most commonly short and smooth, but can be wiry.

Irish Setter.name: Irish Setter
Irish Setter.description: Irish Setters socialize well with children and other dogs. They are affectionate, workaholics, and energetic, so when they are bored, they can be destructive. Often used as therapy dogs, they carry a calming atmosphere.

Irish Terrier.name: Irish Terrier
Irish Terrier.description: Known for their fiery gold-brownish coat, they are courageous and athletic for their size. Irish Terriers need physical and mental challenges to keep itself active and occupied. They love to socialize and have a strong loyalty towards their owners.

Irish Water Spaniel.name: Irish Water Spaniel
Irish Water Spaniel.description: Irish Water Spaniels are recognizable from its its thin 'rat tail' and a curly, thick coat with loose curls from its head covering its head. This spaniel has a natural instinct to want to please. They are very obedient and adore attention, making them a versatile breed in dog competitions.

Irish Wolfhound.name: Irish Wolfhound
Irish Wolfhound.description: A historic breed, the Irish Wolfhound are large fearless hunters, able to hunt and fight both wolves and game. Oftentimes, they hunted far away from their owners, requiring them to be independent thinkers. This trait can still be seen today. The wolfhound has become more affectionate and gentle. They are favoured for their loyalty, affection, and alertness.

Italian Greyhound.name: Italian Greyhound
Italian Greyhound.description: Originally bred, with an instinct for pursuit, to hunt hares, the Italian Greyhounds can sprint up to 60 km/h. Nowadays, they are kept mostly for companion and are even classified in the toy breed group by some Kennel clubs. Their attentiveness and small stature make them great for lap-dogs. They are skiny and have a short coat, requiring care in cold weather.

Japanese Spitzes.name: Japanese Spitzes
Japanese Spitzes.description: Japanese Spitzes are excellent companion dogs that love to please and to be apart of the family. They absolutely enjoy being active and thrive on attention. The breed is increasingly popular due to their loyal, happy, and affectionate temperament. Their fur is surprisingly low maintenance because dirt also does not stick to their fluffy coat. With a natural tendency to bark at arriving strangers, they also make good watchdogs. The breed has very few genetic problems compared to most companion dogs.

Japanese Spaniel.name: Japanese Spaniel
Japanese Spaniel.description: A charming toy breed with a silky coat and of aristocratic bearing, the Japanese Spaniel is quiet and graceful. They are considered to be the most 'cat-like' breed with their independence, usage of its own paws to wash itself, and preference for high surfaces. They are friendly and love to socialize. Historically, they were also bred to entertain their aristocratic owners, dancing with their only two paws and even 'sing'.

Kerry Blue Terrier.name: Kerry Blue Terrier
Kerry Blue Terrier.description: Larger than most terriers, the Kerry Blue Terrier has an amazingly soft and wavy-curly coat with a mixture of gray and blue. Its fur feels like soft wool and humain hair. They are loyal and gentle towards their owners, but can be less so towards any other animal if not trained well. Athletic and intelligent, they perform brilliantly in dog competitions.

Labrador Retriever.name: Labrador Retriever
Labrador Retriever.description: One of the most popular breeds in the world, the gun breed was developed from Canadian fishing dogs that would help recapture any fish that escaped. Regarded highly for their obedience, intelligence, and gentle temperament, these traits make them popular disability assistant breeds as well as detection work for police.

Lakeland Terrier.name: Lakeland Terrier
Lakeland Terrier.description: Similar in appearance to the Welsh Terrier and Airedale, the Lakeland is a sturdy, bushy breed. They have a hard, low-shedding coat. Although they are independent and sometimes aloof, the Lakelands are also very intelligent and can be easy to train. However, daily exercise and socializations are necessary as with most terriers.

Leonberg.name: Leonberg
Leonberg.description: A large and muscular breed, Leonberg has a striking melanistic mask with a thick, water-resistant coat. If they are socialized and trained well, their temperament is self-assured, friendly, and disciplined. They are incredibly playful and intelligent. Leonberg is sexually dimorphic (strongly masculine or feminine) which largely affects their personality.

Lhasa.name: Lhasa
Lhasa.description: It is said the breed's name comes from the Tibetan word for 'billy goat'. Lhasa is a nearly thousand year old breed who were used as companions in the Himalayan monasteries. Its long, thick coat protects it from the cold weather high in the mountains. They can sometimes be aloof, especially towards strangers. Lhasa has a long lifespan and can live healthy for nearly two decades.

Maltese Dog.name: Maltese Dog
Maltese Dog.description: Named after the island of Malta in the Mediterranean, Maltese has always been a popular lap-dog, even dating back to ancient Greeks. They do not shed, making them a good choice to be companions for people with allergies. The breed embodies elegance with its snow white cloak and its smooth bearing. Although they are playful and adaptable, they can also be very stubborn.

Mexican Hairless.name: Mexican Hairless
Mexican Hairless.description: Also known as Xoloitzcuintle, or Xolo for short, the breed is nearly 3000 years old and is named after an Aztec god. They come in many sizes and has a haired variant. The haired variant, with the recessive haired trait, has a short, dark coat. Both variants' skins are often spotted or patterned. Xolo has a primitive and mischievious temperament with a lot of energy, but tend to be more calm when they are old.

Newfoundland.name: Newfoundland
Newfoundland.description: A massive and powerful breed hailing from Newfoundland, Canada, they are excellent at swimming and water rescue with their webbed paws and thick water-resistant coat. Newfoundlands are an amazing companion being both gentle and obedient. The gentle giants are known to drool, especially in hot weather, and have a fondness for mud and water.

Norfolk Terrier.name: Norfolk Terrier
Norfolk Terrier.description: One of the smallest terrie, Norfolks were bred to fearlessly hunt vermin. They appear to be a toy breed, but they can be very feisty, active, and fearless. Like most terriers, Norfolks are obedient and love to socialize with other dogs and people. Their portable size and adaptability make them great to travel.

Norwegian Elkhound.name: Norwegian Elkhound
Norwegian Elkhound.description: The National Dog of Norway, the Elkhound is a sturdy defender, herder, and hunter. They will bravely track, hunt, and fight large animals including moose, bears, and wolves. Their sharp bark and loyalty make them great watchdogs. They are courageous, affectionate, intelligent, independent, and alert, but requires lots of attention and training.

Norwich Terrier.name: Norwich Terrier
Norwich Terrier.description: At less than 30 cm, Norwich are among the smallest terriers. Originally bred as fearless rat hunters to rid farms of pests, their small stature has now made them popular lap-dogs. Despite their tiny legs, they are surprisingly energetic and love to exercise. Norwich are intelligent, loving, and assertive. They are generally great with children but other small pets can be mistaken as their original nemesis: rodents.

Old English Sheepdog.name: Old English Sheepdog
Old English Sheepdog.description: One of the most recognizable breeds with their long, grey, shaggy coat covering their faces and fluffing their paws, the Sheepdog was used to herd livestock. Surprisingly, their long coats do not shed unless they are brushed. They love exercise and to feel the wind blowing back on their long hair. Patient, kind, and watchful, they make amazing playmates and watchdogs.

Pekinese.name: Pekinese
Pekinese.description: A lap-dog bred for the aristocrats of ancient China, Pekinese are confident and independent companions with a unique 'rolling' gait. They have a composed, serene stature and are affectionate towards their owners, however they hate rough play and dislike children who treat them like that. Like pugs and similar toy dogs, excessive breeding to create the 'cutest' Pekingese has caused the breed to suffer terrible health. This includes skull malformation, breathing, back, and eye issues

Pembroke.name: Pembroke
Pembroke.description: Better known as Welsh Corgi or just Corgi, this breed is adored by the British royalty. Queen Elizabeth II has more than 30 for herself. They are very similar to Cardigan Welsh Corgi, but are shorter lengthwise and have smaller ears. Pembrokes shed heavily all year and are very intelligent. Despite that, their strong-will can, at times, make it difficult to train. They love attention and to be with the family.

Pomeranian.name: Pomeranian
Pomeranian.description: Popularized by Queen Victoria who owned a small Pomeranian, the breed is a lively and playful lap-dog. However, they can still be aggressive towards other dogs and people if they are not trained and socialized well. They adore attention and love to play. Their coat, most commonly being orange or white, can vary greatly. It also requires constant grooming because of its thickness and shedding.

Rhodesian Ridgeback.name: Rhodesian Ridgeback
Rhodesian Ridgeback.description: In the 1700s, Europeans described them as ferocious, muscular guard dogs. They were dogs used by Khoikhoi people near Cape Peninsula to track and hunt animals like boars. A stripe of backwards-facing hair trademarks this breed. Rhodesian are loyal, intelligent, and extremely athletic, but can be aloof and assertive towards strangers. Without persistent, justified training and socialization, they can become uncontrollable and too aggressive.

Rottweiler.name: Rottweiler
Rottweiler.description: One of the oldest dog breeds dating back to ancient Rome, Rottweilers were excellent herders and strong protectors for the Roman legions when traveling. Their athleticism, obedience, and courage make them excellent defenders of property, and are still used for the same purposes today. They are intelligent, confident, alert, eager to work, and devoted. If trained well, they have a calm temperament and are only aggressive to protect their family.

Saint Bernard.name: Saint Bernard
Saint Bernard.description: A giant rescue dog from Switzerland, they are renowned for their large stature and gentleness. They are named after the Great St Bernard Hospice where the breed may be used to rescue travelers near the Great St Bernard Pass. The soft giant is a sweet and loyal companion. Still, they require a lot of attention to look after the breed. Their bones can deteriorate if they do not get proper food nor exercise. They must be trained and socialized well to prevent aggression or fearfulness.

Saluki.name: Saluki
Saluki.description: Salukis are elegant, strong hunters that used sight rather than scent to hunt game. They are easily recognized by their long head, droopy ears, and thin body. Their long powerful legs make them the fastest breed, capable of running up to 68.8 km/hr and can run at distances of up to 800 m. Retaining the temperaments of their ancestors, Salukis are independent, aloof, and love to chase anything. They are calm, but can be mischievious if they are not exercised nor socialized.

Samoyed.name: Samoyed
Samoyed.description: Originally used to help hunt, herd reindeers, and pull sleds for the Samoyedes, their happy temperament makes them great companions. Their dense, fluffy white coat keeps the dog warm in their cold homeland. They are very friendly, alert, and very strong. They also love to play so much that they may become destructive to alleviate their boredom.

Scotch Terrier.name: Scotch Terrier
Scotch Terrier.description: One of five Scotland's terriers, the Scotch Terrier was nicknamed 'the diehard' for its independence and touch temperament. They are feisty, courageous, and alert, bred to hunt badgers. Oftentimes, they can be aggressive around other dogs and small mammals if not socialized and trained well. Nonetheless they can still be affectionate, playful, and loyal.

Scottish Deerhound.name: Scottish Deerhound
Scottish Deerhound.description: The large, tough breed was bred to hunt giant red deers by stalking, observing, and chasing, rather than scent. Closely related to the Irish Wolfhound, the Deerhound has a grayish, crispy coat with the size of one of the tallest sighthounds. They are gentle, friendly, and love to please their owners. Deerhounds have an instinctive desire to chase and needs a considerable amount of intensive exercise other than a leashed walk or a small yard to roam.

Sealyham Terrier.name: Sealyham Terrier
Sealyham Terrier.description: Originally bred to hunt small game and pests such as badgers, the fluffy, white breed is more of a family dog now. Its used to be extremely popular around WW1 with many celebrities and the British Royal Family having them. Their popularity declined as more foreign breeds were introduced. Although they can be independent and strong willed, they love company and are very affectionate towards their owners.

Shetland Sheepdog.name: Shetland Sheepdog
Shetland Sheepdog.description: More commonly known as Sheltie, they are a small, but very active dog. They love to please and love to have an active job such as herding livestock, the breed's original purpose. Their attachment to their family is extremely strong. According to Dr. Stanley Coren, Shelties are one of the brightest breeds and are extremely easy to train.

Shiba Dog.name: Shiba Dog
Shiba Dog.description: An ancient, muscular breed selected for hunting as their owners hiked on mountainous terrain, Shiba Inu is now more commonly used as a companion dog. Their temperament is independent and meticulous. They have a strong desire to keep themselves clean: they will lick themselves to clean and avoid dirt on their coat as much as possible. They are extremely proud and will scream if the dog is handled in a way they do not agree with. They may also do a similar scream when they are extremely happy.

Shih Tzu.name: Shih Tzu
Shih Tzu.description: They are also known as Xi Shi dog, named after Xi Shi who was one of the most beautiful women to have ever existed in ancient China. Like Xi Shi, they are beautiful with their long silky coat, often styled and decorated. The breed is playful, friendly, and calm. Unfortunately, Shih Tzu suffers from terrible health even at an early age due to incompetent breeders trying to make the 'cutest dog'. The ideal beauty of the breed's face has caused the skull to be malformed. This has lead to breathing and eye issues.

Siberian Husky.name: Siberian Husky
Siberian Husky.description: The thick coated sled dog is an amazingly strong working dog. Similar to the Alaskan Malamute, they have distinct fur markings on their fluffy coat and pointy ears. They are extremely active and thus have high physical and mental needs or they can be destructive: digging and chewing. If bored enough, they can even climb 2.5m fences to escape and explore. They are generaly friendly, gentle, and independent, but will instinctively hunt small animals.

Staffordshire Bullterrier.name: Staffordshire Bullterrier
Staffordshire Bullterrier.description: A medium, muscular breed, the Staffordshire is a cross-breed descended from Old English Bulldog and Old English Terrier. They are and have always been an amazing companion dog as they are very loyal, brave, and affectionate. They can also be friendly, even to strangers. Unfortunately, they have a stigma of being aggressive and usually owned by the 'lower-class'. As a result, this breed is very common in dog shelters.

Sussex Spaniel.name: Sussex Spaniel
Sussex Spaniel.description: The short, long breed were bred to help hunt on rough terrain with their excellent nose. They are generally not a popular breed and have been close to extinction during the 1900s. Sussex Spaniel is calm, generally laid back, and loves to be around people. They make amazing family dogs and are great with children.

Tibetan Mastiff.name: Tibetan Mastiff
Tibetan Mastiff.description: These ancient giants were powerful guard and herding dogs for Tibetan nomads. Their thick, fluffy coat protects them from the cold and harsh weather of the Himalayan mountains. They are intelligent, strong willed, athletic, and standoffish towards strangers. Through consistent discipline, training, and socialization, the dog can also be affectionate and loyal to their family.

Tibetan Terrier.name: Tibetan Terrier
Tibetan Terrier.description: This breed is actually not a terrier, despite its name. Tsang Apso is its Tibetan name meaning a shappy dog. They were kept as good luck charms and companions who were also alert. Like most breeds from Tibet, they are powerful and can move well across rough terrain such as a hill in the Himalayans. Their coat can have all types of colours and patterns. They make excellent family dogs as they are affectionate, gentle, and not prone to barking. Tibetan Terriers do, however, need an active lifestyle and do excellent in dog sporting competitions.

Walker Hound.name: Walker Hound
Walker Hound.description: Also known as Treeing Walker Coonhound or TWC, this breed was mostly used to hunt raccoons, bears, or cougars. They are very fast and will chase to hunt small animals like quirrels and opossums. Like most hunting dogs, they are now mostly kept as companions. They are very affectionate and active, so they must be trained and exercise a lot.

Weimaraner.name: Weimaraner
Weimaraner.description: Weimaraner is an general gun dog used by royalty to hunt bears, deers, and foxes. However, as large game hunting declined in popularity, so did this breed's popularity. They started being used for hunting smaller game and still is today. Like a typical gun dog, they are extremely athletic, intelligent, brave, and have a great sense of smell. Weimaraner excel at tracking and love to work with their owners. They can have anxiety if they are alone from their owners for too long.

Welsh Springer Spaniel.name: Welsh Springer Spaniel
Welsh Springer Spaniel.description: Welshies are known for being a great family dog with their affectionate temperament, happy disposition, and its great looks with their fluffy, rich red coat. Some can be very clingy and may even suffer separation anxiety when separated from their owners for too long. They can be impulsive and with gentle training, they can be very obedient. Without that nor consistent exercise, they will be distressed and hyperactive. The breed is so old that their ancestry is unknown, but it is presumed that they descended from the old Land Spaniel.

West Highland White Terrier.name: West Highland White Terrier
West Highland White Terrier.description: One of the most recognizable terriers, the Westie, originally bred to hunt rodents, is now a popular, independent, and friendly, family companion. They are very social and have a happy disposition. In modern culture, the breed is often depicted in brands for mascots or dog foods because they are very cute with their cheerful impression and fluffy, snow white coat.

Yorkshire Terrier.name: Yorkshire Terrier
Yorkshire Terrier.description: One of the smallest breeds, Yorkshires are playful and clingy. Their compact size and hypoallergenic fur make them excellent toy dogs, however, they still exhibit the traits of a terrier. They are feisty and self-confident. Nonetheless, they still love attention and a close companionship with their owners.

Affenpinscher.name: Affenpinscher
Affenpinscher.description: This adventurous, playful, and affectionate toy terrier was originally bred to hunt rodents from kitchens, but they are now loyal companions. Affenpinscher's appearance is often described as 'monkey dogs' or 'Ewoks' for their shaggy, harsh coat that comes mostly in dark black. Their rough fur does not shed much, but consistent grooming is still needed.

Basenji.name: Basenji
Basenji.description: Hailing from Africa, these hunting dogs were prized for their intelligence, athleticism, and courage. Their unusual larynx allows Basenji to yodel instead of bark. They have a graceful, yet self-assured gait resembling a galloping horse. So, as you would expect, they love to run and are best with owners who are also athletic and can challenge them physically.

Basset.name: Basset
Basset.description: Do not be fooled by their short, stubby legs! Their legs are powerfully built for endurance, allowing Bassets to gracefully move. They were bred for tracking hare with the use of their excellent sense of smell, and then stalking them with their enduring paws. Their short stature, however, is due to dwarfism and may suffer from bone problems. They require patient training. Bassets are very friendly, social, and affectionate, making them great family dogs.

Beagle.name: Beagle
Beagle.description: Beagles are excellent hunting dogs that hunted small game in packs with their amazing scenting abilities. They have one of the best senses of smell of any breed and are often used as a detection dog. However, they are better at ground-scenting than air-scenting, so Beagles are not usually used in rescue. They are energetic and love to socialize. Their loyalty, happy and playful temperament make them great family dogs.

Black and Tan Coonhound.name: Black and Tan Coonhound
Black and Tan Coonhound.description: Their striking, coal black can be intimidating and tenacious, but Coonhounds can also be loving, calm, and amiable. They are gentle, indepedent, and make good family dogs, but when their hunting instincts take over, Coonhounds will be fixated in tracking. With their Bloodhound ancestry, they have an amazing scenting ability that can effortlessly track game such as bear and wolves. Coonhounds are quite healthy, but they drool a lot and need regular care to wipe their face and check their ears against infections.

Bloodhound.name: Bloodhound
Bloodhound.description: The famed sniffer, the legendary Bloodhound can discern smell over many miles and days. Its extraordinary sense of smell make them excellent hunters for any game and are loved by law enforcements to track missing people. They are obedient and gentle, but will be independent and work tirelessly to follow a scent. To train this super dog, their initial tracking experience should be extremely enjoyable. They should be regularly trained with vary situations and increasing difficulty.

Bluetick.name: Bluetick
Bluetick.description: The Bluetick Coonhound is a quick and brave breed with a 'blue' coat which comes from its black fur marking its faded white coat. They were originally raccoon hunters, so they are bred to be strong, hardy, and to love to have a job to keep them active. Despite being obedient, they can be difficult to train and control when Blueticks are near small mammals as their hunting instincts can take over. Once trained however, Blueticks are very affectionate and social, even towards strangers.

Borzoi.name: Borzoi
Borzoi.description: This large Russian speedster, named after the Russian word 'fast', is great wolf and fox hunter by surveying and chasing. Their furry coat can be of any colour or pattern. It is often wavy and thick to protect them against the harsh Russian winters. Borzois are very gentle, quiet, loves to do dog competitions, and are affectionate, especially towards their owners,. When training, they are easily hurt by punishments and harsh training. Borzois also easily get bored with repetitive tasks, and can be difficult to train.

Boxer.name: Boxer
Boxer.description: Developed in Germany from bulldogs to pursuit bears and boars, Boxers have a powerful jaw to strongly seize their prey and hold them down until their owners arrive to finish the game. Boxers are extremely affectionate and faithful towards their owners, but they will be wary of any strangers. If raised well, they are a playful breed and will patiently care for and protect children that they trust. Unfortunately, Boxers are prone to cancer and cardiac issues. They will require attention, both physically and socially.

Briard.name: Briard
Briard.description: This furry breed was originally bred to herd sheep and protect them from wild animals such as wolves or even themselves! Of course, they are bred to be extremely brave and loyal to stand up to menaces like wolves. They are very trainable, smart, and protective. Briads are well known for their wavy coat that will fly in the wind as they run.

Bull Mastiff.name: Bull Mastiff
Bull Mastiff.description: The large guardians were bred to scare of poachers with their muscular body ripping through their short coat. They are a an alert protector and a great game hunter; bull Mastiffs are tough, speedy, and aggressive. Nonetheless, they can be very delicate towards their owners, and therefore require gentle, yet consistent, training and socialization. They love to have a physical job to keep them active: tracking, running, or carting.

Cairn.name: Cairn
Cairn.description: Cairn is a happy and fearless terrier. Always curious and observant, they love to explore and dig holes. Like most other small terriers, they are obedient, active, and easily trainable as they were originally bred to hunt vermins. Their weather resistant coat allows them to endure the harsh rains of Scotland while they freely roam and explore outside to kill rats. Their fluffy coat needs a lot of attention and should be hand groomed.

Chinese Rural Dog.name: Chinese Rural Dog
Chinese Rural Dog.description: Chinese Rural Dog is not actually a singular pure breed like most other dogs in this app. It is an umbrella term for common, domestic, mixed breeds in China and often synonymous with 'stray dog'. As a result, its physical appearance and temperament can vary greatly. Recently, China has banned owning certain breeds that would be considered a 'Chinese Rural Dog' as they wanted to prevent the number of stray dogs increasing.

Chow.name: Chow
Chow.description: One of the oldest breeds that is said to date back 2000 years ago in Northern China, Chow (or Chow Chow) is a sturdy breed that were used to pull dog sleds in rough terrain. Over the many centuries however, this breed has changed a lot and are mostly kept as companions. Nonetheless, Chow Chows kept their protectiveness, strength, and can be surprisingly aggressive, especially when their owners or their property are threatened. They develop very deep and strong bonds. Chow Chows are also often quiet and stubborn.

Clumber.name: Clumber
Clumber.description: This fluffy, white breed is the largest of the spaniel group, towering at half a meter. Clumber Spaniel is known for its creamy white fur that elegantly floats in the wind with their freckled, powerful nose. They are very loyal, gentle, and loving towards people they trust, but will be cold towards strangers. Clumber does require quite a bit of care as they frequently shed and love to carry things which can unfortunately be swallowed and cause problems.

Cocker Spaniel.name: Cocker Spaniel
Cocker Spaniel.description: This refers to two different breeds: the English Cocker Spaniel and the American Cocker Spaniel. The American variant is slightly smaller than the British variant. Developed as gun hunting dogs, they are now popular family companions, often groomed to show off their beautiful, wavy hair. They are fun, sweet, and love to play. They are also quite intelligent, allowing them to be easily trained as companions or dog competition athlete.

Collie.name: Collie
Collie.description: The Collie is one of the most recognizable breeds with their pointed snouts and long, thick coat. They are extremely athletic and agile, so much that they can run all day without being tired. With a very strong herding instinct, they love to run and chase, almost obsessively. This makes them excellent in dog herding competitions. Collies are extremely loyal, affectionate, and energetic, which also make them great family companions if they are given an open field to run all day long.

Curly Coated Retriever.name: Curly Coated Retriever
Curly Coated Retriever.description: One of the most distinctive breeds with their muscular retriever body and short, dark curly coat, hence its name. Their curly coat is very dense, making it, in a way, water-resistant while also allowing it to endure more damage that other straight, long haired dogs cannot endure. As most gun dogs are, the Curly Coated Retriever is extremely active, intelligent, and affectionate. They are usually aloof towards strangers.

Dhole.name: Dhole
Dhole.description: Dhole is actually not a dog. They are not even in the same genus as wolves (Dholes' genus is Cuon)! Nonetheless, they are genetically close to the genus Canis. Their red, short fur and erect round ears make them resemble foxes. They are extremely social, living in large packs with whom they hunt deers together early in the morning.

Dingo.name: Dingo
Dingo.description: Dingo, an ancient dog of nearly 3500 years, is often debated whether it is a domestic dog (Canis familiaris) or its own subspecies of wolves (Canis lupus dingo). They are mostly accepted as the latter where their lineage split from its ancestors in South Eastern Asia about 8000 years ago. Dingos are more solitary than most other wolf descendant animals; their packs mostly consist of their mate and possibly with their offspring. They are strong and learn, hunting kangaroos, geese, rats, and rabbits.

Flat Coated Retriever.name: Flat Coated Retriever
Flat Coated Retriever.description: The Float Coated Retriever is a strong, active breed with a love for doing jobs and pleasing their owners. They are extremely social, intelligent, affectionate, and confident. Developed as a gun dog to retrieve game, they have a powerful jaw to hold game and deliver it back to their owners. Sometimes game fall into water, so the breed was developed to swim extremely well - so much, in fact, that the modern breed loves to swim. They are excellent companions for those with an active lifestyle.

Giant Schnauzer.name: Giant Schnauzer
Giant Schnauzer.description: Giant Schnauzers, despite their friendly appearance, are actually capable guard dogs and popular military dogs, being used in WW1 and WW2. This is due to their distrust of strangers and are extremely territorial. Although Giant Schnauzers are usually reserved, they will be aggressive to protect their owners and territory. They are extremely intelligent and loyal, allowing them to be easily trained.

Golden Retriever.name: Golden Retriever
Golden Retriever.description: One of the most popular breed in the world, their lushious, creamy coat is an extremely friendly and gentle companion, even towards strangers. They were originally bred to retrieve dead ducks and birds back to their owners undamaged with their soft mouths. Their beautiful, thick coat repels water allowing them to swim without getting cold. Golden Retrievers are extremely obedient, intelligent, eager to please, and loving. These traits make them excellent disability assistance dogs.

Groenendael.name: Groenendael
Groenendael.description: Groenendael is a variant of the Belgian Shepherd which its coat being sharp black and long. They are intelligent, brave, alert, and hard working. However, they can also be quick tempered which can make them inappropriate family dogs. As a result of their temperaments, they are great for assistance, military, and rescue type jobs. Groenendael are powerful working dogs that love to run and exercise. They are best suited with an owner with an active lifestyle.

Keeshond.name: Keeshond
Keeshond.description: The fluffy, lovable spitz is a medium-sized companion that is notable for its fox-like face. Keeshonds were the symbol of Netherlands' Patriot faction, a political party around the 1780s kindled by the French Revolution. They have a thick double coat, like most spitz, which requires regular brushing to maintain beautiful and soft fur.

Kelpie.name: Kelpie
Kelpie.description: Kelpie is a medium sheep dog that can herd livestock independently. They are strongly motivated by their herding instinct and love to have a job. There are multiple variants depending on their purpose of when they were bred: show breed and working breed. They have slight physical differences. Excelling in agility dog competitions and obedience, Kelpies are easy to train and great family companions.

Komondor.name: Komondor
Komondor.description: Also known as the Hungarian sheepdog, they are a guardian dog bred to protect and herd livestock like sheep. As it happens, the breed looks exactly like a sheep! Their strange coat is composed of long, white cords dangling down like the end of a mop. They are calm and affectionate, but will be fearless and defend itself and their family under trouble.
